title: U.K.’s Stamp Duty Hits Pricey Areas the Hardest
text:
Since the introduction of new stamp duty tax rates in 2014 that included a sharp increase for buyers of prime property, real estate transactions across England have fallen, with the wealthiest areas of the country being the hardest hit, according to a report Wednesday by estate agency Benham and Reeves.



Stamp duty is the tax paid on the purchase of a residential property in England priced at more than £125,000 (US$156,686).



More: Colorful Notting Hill Apartment Lists for £2.475 Million

The tax rate increases in hand with the sale price and is subject to a 3% surcharge if the property is a second home or buy-to-let residence. First-time buyers are exempt from stamp duty if their purchase costs less than £500,000.



For purchases of more than £1.5 million, rates were hiked from 7% to 12% in 2014.



Overall transaction levels across England since the changes have fallen by 0.8%, the report said.



But transaction declines were the worst in Kensington and Chelsea. The London borough is the most expensive enclave in the country, with the average house price currently standing at £2 million, according to a recent house price index. Transactions in the neighborhood have dropped 21.2% since the new rates were introduced, the report said.



The City of Westminster, the next most expensive area in England, where homes cost an average of £1.4 million, has seen the second largest declines in transaction levels, down 20.5%.

The two affluent neighborhoods were followed by London’s Tower Hamlets where transactions have dropped 20.2% since the stamp duty changes; in wealthy Elmbridge, Surrey, transactions fell 18.7%; and in Cambridge they dropped 18%.



“The government’s re-shuffle has dented buyer sentiment across the board, particularly at the top end of the market,” said Marc von Grundherr, director of Benham and Reeves, in the report. “Of course, those buying a home at the highest-price threshold may be better able to afford stamp duty, but a steep increase has left many thinking twice.”



The government should seriously consider scrapping their archaic money grab to help stimulate an otherwise weary housing market, as tinkering with the nuts and bolts has done nothing to help,” Mr. von Grundherr said.



Prime Minister Boris Johnson has already been mulling reversing the increased rates of stamp duty on homes sold for over £1.5 million, as well as abolishing the tax on homes sold for less than £500,000, Mansion Global previously reported.
